content:
Burnley Borough Council is reportedly the only council in the UK where no employee was recorded as earning over £100,000 in the 2023/24 accounts — yet the Chief Executive's salary band is listed as £120,000+ in the Pay Policy Statement. This discrepancy may have a perfectly reasonable explanation, but it raises transparency questions that the council should address.

The Discrepancy

Two official documents tell different stories:

  • The Pay Policy Statement — which councils are required to publish annually — lists the Chief Executive's salary band as £120,000 or above
  • The 2023/24 Statement of Accounts — which councils are required to publish under the Accounts and Audit Regulations — records zero employees earning over £100,000

If the Chief Executive is paid £120,000+, why does no one appear in the over-£100,000 disclosure?

Possible Explanations

There are several legitimate reasons why the disclosure might not show any employee over £100,000:

Explanation How It Would Work Transparency Concern
Part-year employment CE started or left partway through the year, so actual pay was below £100K Low — timing is a valid reason
Pension adjustments The disclosure may be based on taxable pay after pension contributions are deducted Medium — the headline salary is still £120K+
Salary sacrifice The CE may participate in salary sacrifice schemes that reduce gross pay Medium — total remuneration cost to taxpayer may still exceed £100K
Accounting treatment Different definitions of "remuneration" in accounts vs pay policy High — if definitions vary, comparability is lost
Disclosure error The accounts may simply contain an error or omission High — accuracy of published accounts is fundamental

How Burnley Compares

Council CEO Salary (Pay Policy) Employees >£100K (Accounts) Discrepancy?
Burnley £120,000+ 0 Yes
Hyndburn ~£110,000 1 No
Pendle ~£105,000 1 No

Both neighbouring councils show consistency between their pay policy statements and their accounts disclosures. Burnley is the outlier.

The Transparency Code Requirement

The Local Government Transparency Code 2015 requires councils to publish:

  • The number of employees whose remuneration exceeds £50,000 in bands of £5,000
  • Senior officer remuneration including salary, expenses, bonuses, compensation for loss of office, and employer pension contributions
  • A pay policy statement showing the relationship between the highest-paid employee and the median salary

The purpose of these requirements is to ensure public transparency over how taxpayer money is used to remunerate senior officials. When the published data contains apparent contradictions, that transparency objective is undermined.

Why This Matters

This is not primarily about the amount the Chief Executive is paid. District council chief executives across England earn in the range of £100,000-£150,000, and Burnley's salary level appears consistent with comparable authorities.

The issue is transparency and accuracy:

  • If the accounts are correct and no one earned over £100K, the pay policy statement may be misleading
  • If the pay policy is correct and the CE earns £120K+, the accounts disclosure may be incomplete
  • Either way, one of two published official documents appears to be inaccurate
  • Residents and researchers comparing council pay across England would reach the wrong conclusion about Burnley

The Full Remuneration Picture

Salary is only one component of executive remuneration. The full cost to the taxpayer includes:

  • Basic salary: The headline pay figure
  • Employer pension contributions: Typically 15-20% of salary for the Local Government Pension Scheme
  • National Insurance contributions: Employer NI at 13.8% above the threshold
  • Any allowances or benefits: Car allowance, telephone, etc.
  • Expenses: Travel, subsistence, accommodation

For a CEO on a salary of £120,000, the total cost to the taxpayer including employer pension and NI contributions could be in the region of £155,000-£165,000 per year.

Questions That Need Answering

  1. How many employees earned over £100,000 including pension contributions in 2023/24? The gross cost to the taxpayer is what matters.
  2. What is the full remuneration package for the Chief Executive? Salary, pension, NI, allowances, and expenses should all be disclosed.
  3. Why does the accounts disclosure differ from the pay policy statement? A clear explanation for the discrepancy should be published.
  4. Has this discrepancy been raised with the external auditors? If so, what was their view?
  5. Is this a one-off or a pattern? Do previous years' accounts show the same discrepancy?
  6. What is the CEO-to-median pay ratio? The pay policy should disclose this, but is it calculated correctly if the CEO salary is not accurately reflected?

This article is based on publicly available information including Burnley Borough Council's Pay Policy Statement, Statement of Accounts 2023/24, and the Local Government Transparency Code. We are not suggesting any wrongdoing — there may be a straightforward accounting explanation for the discrepancy. If the council provides clarification, we will update this article accordingly. This analysis does not constitute financial, employment, or legal advice.
